channel.title: BBC News | Health | World Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Alarm at human bird flu cluster
item.description: The WHO says it is very worried about a cluster of recent human deaths from bird flu in Indonesia.

item.title: UN report flags up India drug use
item.description: A UN report highlights concern over rising drug abuse and its impact on the spread of HIV in north-eastern India.

item.title: Sleeping may help keep you slim
item.description: A good night's sleep may keep you slim as well as refreshed, research suggests.

item.title: Herceptin set for EU approval
item.description: The breast cancer drug Herceptin is set to be licensed for use for early stages of the disease by European regulators.

item.title: Eye warning call for cigarettes
item.description: Experts are calling for cigarette packets to carry a warning that smoking can cause blindness.

item.title: Brain illness nightmare for boys
item.description: A family in Leicester is devastated to discover three young brothers all have a terminal brain illness.

item.title: Pill 'reverses' vegetative state
item.description: A sleeping pill can temporarily revive people in a permanent vegetative state, a study finds.

item.title: Doctors attack 'bogus' therapies
item.description: A group of leading doctors urges NHS trusts to abandon the use of "unproven" alternative medicines.

item.title: Physical clues to Alzheimer's
item.description: Walking and balance problems may predict Alzheimer's disease, research suggests.

item.title: Hard knocks make gullible adults
item.description: A study from the University of Leicester finds individuals who suffer a troubled childhood and adolescence are easily misled.

item.title: WHO chief dies after blood clot
item.description: The head of the World Health Organization, Lee Jong-wook, dies after suffering from a blood clot on the brain.

item.title: Legal bid over junk food ad ban
item.description: The TV regulator Ofcom could be taken to court to force it to consider a pre-watershed ban on junk food advertising.

item.title: Panel backs drug-injecting rooms
item.description: A panel of experts urges the government to set up rooms in the UK where heroin users could legally inject drugs.

item.title: Cats 'raise risk of child eczema'
item.description: Children exposed to cats soon after birth may have an increased risk of developing eczema, a study suggests.

item.title: UK heart drug policy 'not enough'
item.description: The UK's policy for giving cholesterol-lowering drugs to prevent heart disease is inadequate, experts say.

item.title: Nine killed by fake Chinese drug
item.description: Nine patients have died after being injected with a fake drug in southern China, hospital officials say.

item.title: Fewer NHS beds 'but better care'
item.description: People are getting better care despite the number of beds falling by a third in the last 20 years, managers say.

item.title: Cancer: The facts
item.description: The disease tends to affect older people - but can strike at any time.

item.title: Pregnancy timeline
item.description: A week by week guide to pregnancy taking in how the baby develops, changes to the mother and key scan dates.
